greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Starting from A003961(n), the number of additional iterations of A003961 required for the result to be of the form 4k+1.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10001
example: a(5) = 2, because exactly two additional iterations of A003961 are needed before A003961(5) = 7 is of the form 4k+1; as A003961(7) = 11 and A003961(11) = 13. (We have 7 = 3 mod 4, 11 = 3 mod 4 and 13 = 1 mod 4.)
program: A003961(n) = my(f = factor(n)); for (i=1, #f~, f[i, 1] = nextprime(f[i, 1]+1)); factorback(f); \\ Using code of _Michel Marcus_
(Scheme, two different variants, the second one employing memoizing definec-macro)
(define (A246271 n) (let loop ((i 0) (n n)) (let ((next (A003961 n))) (if (= 1 (modulo next 4)) i (loop (+ i 1) next)))))
xref: A246261 gives the positions of zeros, A246263 the positions of nonzeros.
A246280 the positions where n occurs for the first time, A246167 the positions of new distinct values.
results.author: _Antti Karttunen_, Aug 21 2014
